body:
Hi there,

I can't seem to replicate it. Can you show your code?

With your example HTML in try.jsoup: https://try.jsoup.org/~KDhcX48QN1pnbYhCj-WlusIyAWo

The result of `body.text()` is:

```
TEXT 1 DKLASJD: DASDSA ABT 31321 MT / LSMGO ABT dsada MT TEXT 2 TEXT 3
```

Which is the same as Chrome's rendered output:

```
TEXT 1

DKLASJD:  DASDSA ABT  31321 MT /  LSMGO  ABT dsada MT
TEXT 2
TEXT 3
```

I looked into the example you shared [here](https://try.jsoup.org/~KDhcX48QN1pnbYhCj-WlusIyAWo). I copied both the "input HTML" and the "renderer output" into an HTML renderer, and it seems like the HTML structure is being reordered, as shown in the attached image. I should also mention I'm using version 1.18.3 (which I believe is the latest version) as per https://github.com/jhy/jsoup/blob/master/CHANGES.md. Interestingly, in the example you sent, the text appears in the correct order, but the HTML itself is still being rearranged. Do you know why this might be happening?

Sorry, but I can't make out what you're trying to show me in that image.

Given how badly formed the HTML is (incorrect closers for formatters, etc) there is a chance that the [adoption agency algorithm](https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/parsing.html#adoption-agency-algorithm) is being executed differently by jsoup and (what browser are you testing? You haven't disclosed that). Or something akin.

To get to the bottom of it, my suggestion would be to write some debug code that traces the specific order of the DOM for both jsoup and browser. Add IDs to each element so we can see which one is which. Then traverse the doc and serialize the tag + ID. For the browser you can do this in JS. Then the difference is likely to be apparent.

But I am confused as to why my original output is different to yours. Can you show your code and confirm which version you're on.

Hi Jonathan, I created a repository with a failing unit test, a readme that explains the issue, and a simplified HTML file that replicates the problem: https://github.com/yonigibbs/jsoup-text-reorder. Hopefully this should clarify the issue a bit.

Also, apologies about the input HTML: it is pretty malformed! Unfortunately this is representative of some HTML we receive in some customer data.

OK looking at this -- I believe that the issue lies in the adoption agency algorithm. Our [implementation](https://github.com/jhy/jsoup/blob/1b36b066948a2e25caca1fafe54d5210a95a3b35/src/main/java/org/jsoup/parser/HtmlTreeBuilderState.java#L834) is currently a bit different from the [spec](https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/parsing.html#adoption-agency-algorithm). The spec has been updated since our last implementation.

Need to review and find where the difference is.

issue.title: Reimplement the adoption agency algorithm

repository.name: jsoup
repository.description: jsoup: the Java HTML parser, built for HTML editing, cleaning, scraping, and XSS safety.

issue.body:
Fixes #2267

The implementation of the adoption agency algorithm vs the HTML5 spec had drifted over time. This fixes that.

The spec for table fostering when in adoption is not presently implemented, marked as a todo.

Given the complexity of the algo and how it has changed over time, I opted to include it inline so that hopefully later changes are easier to _adopt_.

body:
Alright, done! That was a bit of a slog.

@yonigibbs thanks for simplifying the reproduction HTML. I included it in the test suite.

Oh wow, amazing! That PR does indeed look like a slog. Love all the comments in the code: makes it very understandable. Great work!

Thanks very much for fixing this. We really appreciate it! (And the library in general: it's fundamental to a lot of stuff we do.)

Do you have a rough idea of when we might expect a release with this fix in it? Just trying to decide whether we should wait for that or consider just building off `master` and grabbing the artifact ourselves locally.

Cheers!

Thanks for the feedback! If you like, I'd be glad to hear more details of what you're using jsoup for, it helps prioritize the roadmap. Here or via email is fine.

As to the next release, I am hoping in the next week or so. But, if you take a snapshot now, that's a a good opportunity to validate the change against your corpus, and potentially find other differences or issues.

Ah, great, as soon as that for the next release: that's perfect, we'll just wait for the release (totally no rush). If I get a chance before then I'll do some testing with the snapshot build and let you know if I find anything.

In terms of what we use JSoup for: we use it to parse HTML received in emails. This is why the HTML that turned up this issue is so bonkers: there's a lot of old email clients out there that seem to generate really quite bizarre HTML ðŸ˜‚. So we parse the HTML, then do some stuff with it, e.g. sanitise some CSS, extract text from it, extract information from it around inline images, etc.
